cards.back: The quantity of a good or service consumers are willing and able to buy at various prices during a specific time period.

cards.front: What does the law of demand state?
cards.back: As price increases, quantity demanded decreases, and vice versa (inverse relationship), ceteris paribus.

cards.front: Why does the demand curve slope downward?
cards.back: 1) Substitution effect (cheaper alternatives), 2) Income effect (purchasing power changes), 3) Diminishing marginal utility.

cards.front: What are the determinants of demand (shift factors)?
cards.back: 1) Consumer income, 2) Prices of related goods, 3) Consumer tastes/preferences, 4) Expectations, 5) Number of buyers.

cards.front: What are normal vs. inferior goods?
cards.back: Normal: demand increases as income increases. Inferior: demand decreases as income increases.
Substitutes: goods that replace each other (price of one ↑, demand for other ↑). Complements: goods used together (price of one ↑, demand for other ↓).
The quantity of a good or service producers are willing and able to sell at various prices during a specific time period.

cards.front: What does the law of supply state?
cards.back: As price increases, quantity supplied increases, and vice versa (direct relationship), ceteris paribus.

cards.front: Why does the supply curve slope upward?
cards.back: Higher prices make production more profitable, encouraging firms to produce more despite rising marginal costs.

cards.front: What are the determinants of supply (shift factors)?
cards.back: 1) Input prices, 2) Technology, 3) Taxes/subsidies, 4) Producer expectations, 5) Number of sellers, 6) Price of related outputs.
Where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied. No tendency for price to change.
The price at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.
The quantity bought and sold at the equilibrium price.

cards.front: What happens when there is a surplus (excess supply)?
cards.back: Price is above equilibrium. Quantity supplied > quantity demanded. Price falls to eliminate surplus.

cards.front: What happens when there is a shortage (excess demand)?
cards.back: Price is below equilibrium. Quantity demanded > quantity supplied. Price rises to eliminate shortage.

cards.front: What is price elasticity of demand?
cards.back: Measures how responsive quantity demanded is to price changes: % change in quantity demanded / % change in price.
|Ed| > 1. Quantity demanded is very responsive to price changes. Demand curve appears relatively flat.
|Ed| < 1. Quantity demanded is not very responsive to price changes. Demand curve appears relatively steep.

cards.front: What does unit elastic demand mean?
cards.back: |Ed| = 1. Percentage change in quantity equals percentage change in price.

cards.front: What factors affect price elasticity of demand?
cards.back: 1) Availability of substitutes, 2) Necessity vs luxury, 3) Proportion of income spent, 4) Time horizon.
|Ed| = ∞. Horizontal demand curve. Consumers buy any quantity at one price, none at any higher price.
|Ed| = 0. Vertical demand curve. Quantity demanded does not respond to price changes.

cards.front: What is the total revenue test for elasticity?
cards.back: If price and total revenue move in opposite directions: demand is elastic. If they move together: demand is inelastic. If TR unchanged: unit elastic.

cards.front: What is price elasticity of supply?
cards.back: Measures how responsive quantity supplied is to price changes: % change in quantity supplied / % change in price.

cards.front: What factors affect price elasticity of supply?
cards.back: 1) Time (more elastic in long run), 2) Production flexibility, 3) Availability of inputs, 4) Excess capacity.

cards.front: What is income elasticity of demand?
cards.back: Measures how responsive demand is to income changes: % change in quantity demanded / % change in income.

cards.front: What does positive vs. negative income elasticity indicate?
cards.back: Positive: normal good (demand ↑ as income ↑). Negative: inferior good (demand ↓ as income ↑).

cards.front: What is cross-price elasticity of demand?
cards.back: Measures how demand for one good responds to price changes of another: % change in quantity demanded of good X / % change in price of good Y.

cards.front: What does positive vs. negative cross-price elasticity indicate?
cards.back: Positive: substitutes (price of Y ↑, demand for X ↑). Negative: complements (price of Y ↑, demand for X ↓).
The difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay. Area below demand curve and above price.
The difference between what producers receive and the minimum they're willing to accept. Area above supply curve and below price.
Consumer surplus + producer surplus. Measures total net benefits to society from market exchange.
The reduction in total surplus caused by market inefficiency (e.g., price controls, taxes).
When resources are allocated to produce the goods and services most valued by society (where P = MC).
Producing at the lowest possible cost (on the production possibilities frontier).
A legal maximum price set below equilibrium. Creates shortage. Example: rent control.
A legal minimum price set above equilibrium. Creates surplus. Example: minimum wage.

cards.front: What are the effects of a tax on market outcomes?
cards.back: Reduces quantity traded, creates deadweight loss, and is shared by buyers and sellers based on relative elasticities.
How the burden of a tax is divided between buyers and sellers. Depends on relative elasticities.

cards.front: What is the relationship between elasticity and tax incidence?
cards.back: The more inelastic side bears more of the tax burden. If demand is more inelastic than supply, consumers pay more of the tax.
A payment to producers or consumers to encourage production or consumption. Increases quantity traded.
A legal limit on the quantity that can be produced or sold. Creates deadweight loss.
Illegal market where goods are traded at prices above legal limits (price ceilings) or outside legal restrictions.
